text:
Getting a job doesn’t solve everything.

You can have a big salary and still feel empty.

You can get into a MAANG company and still cry yourself to sleep.

You can climb the ladder and still feel lost.


Success means nothing if peace is missing.
Maybe we need to stop chasing “titles”…
And start chasing “balance.”

I’ve seen people cry after a rejection.
Not because they didn’t get the job…
But because the process broke them.

– Ghosted after 6 rounds.
– No feedback after weeks of effort.
– False promises about salary, role, and growth.

Every job seeker deserves dignity.
Because behind every application is a story:
– A fresh graduate supporting their family.
– A laid-off employee trying to rebuild.
– A parent who just wants stability for their kids.

A simple ‘Thank you, we appreciate your time’ can bring hope.
A little empathy can bring healing.

HR is not just about filling roles.
It’s about shaping lives.
Please don’t forget the human in human resources.

Job description: We need a rockstar, ninja, hustler…
Salary: 12k stipend.

Bhai, ninja bhi Zomato join kar le isse acha.

You didn’t get rejected because you’re not good enough.
You didn’t get ghosted because your skills are weak.
You didn’t get that “We’ll get back to you” mail because you lacked effort.

The truth is:

* Many job postings already have someone in mind.
* Many interviews are just for compliance.
* Many “recruitment processes” are designed to exploit hope, not talent.

But here’s what they can’t take away from you:
✔ Your skills that you’ve built brick by brick.
✔ Your resilience that kept you going despite rejections.
✔ Your fire to grow, even when the world is unfair.

To every job seeker reading this:
You are not your rejection mail.
You are not “we found someone else.”
You are proof that courage exists in human form.

One “yes” is all it takes.
And it’s coming your way. 💙

If you’re looking, comment **“open to work”** – let’s create visibility (along with the role that you're looking for)

If you’re hiring, please drop opportunities below – you might just change someone’s life today.

Please spend 1 minute to read this post - 

My trust in humanity has sunk deeper today.

Just saw someone's post that they have been posting for the last 2 years.

They post the same thing every 3–5 days –
"A humble request – I am jobless..."

Each post gets 8000+ likes and 500+ comments.

Many people in the comments said they reached out with opportunities, but he never replied.

Because the numbers never added - 2 years ago he posted that I have been jobless for 3 years, this year he posted 2 years etc.

Even I asked him, let me mentor you free. I sent him some job postings. No reply. Nothing.

That person now has 25k+ followers and is doing paid sponsorships.

The cry for help is no longer a cry for survival.
It has become a strategy for attention.

And this is heartbreaking.

Because every time someone fakes struggle for reach, the ones genuinely struggling lose trust.
The people who really need jobs… end up being ignored.
The kindness of strangers gets exploited.
The community becomes numb to real pain.

If you’re ever tempted to “game” vulnerability –
please remember:
Your temporary clout is costing someone else their opportunity to survive.

Not everything is content.
Some things are sacred.
And the pain of survival should never be a marketing tool.

Next time, please check the profile of people - this person came out as a con artist.

I didn’t get rejected from a company.
I got rejected by 57 companies.

Not in one year.
In a single day.

Some never replied.
Some ghosted after 5 rounds.
Some said, “We’re looking for someone with more stability.”
Some just stopped posting the job after interviews.

At first, I thought: Maybe I’m not good enough.
But then I realized - this wasn’t a reflection of my skills.
It was a reflection of a broken hiring system.

Because talent doesn’t vanish with one rejection.
Potential doesn’t expire because of HR silence.
And your worth is not defined by an ATS filter.

To anyone struggling right now -
Your rejection letter is not the final word.
It’s just a detour.

One “YES” is enough to erase 100 “NOs.”
One door can change your whole life.

And when that door opens -
You’ll look back and thank every single rejection that didn’t work out.

Because rejections don’t break you.
They build you.

🔥 Remember this: You are not your rejections. You are your resilience.

The Real Reason People Quit -

It’s rarely just about money.
It’s about:

Feeling invisible in meetings.

Never hearing a ‘thank you.’

Being treated like a resource instead of a person.

We think attrition is solved with better pay and perks.
But sometimes, it’s solved by basic human decency.

Corporate has a silent bias.

The woman who dresses up, wears heels, red lipstick, and looks “polished” - is called confident, ambitious, leadership material.

The woman who chooses comfort over contour - plain clothes, no makeup, no heels — is often overlooked. Sometimes even judged.

But think about it…
Why is confidence linked to lipstick?
Why is competence tied to high heels?
Why can’t comfort and capability coexist?

Not every woman wants to “play pretty” just to be respected.
Some of us want to play real.

I don’t want to spend hours in front of the mirror.
I don’t want to wear lipstick to prove I’m confident.
I don’t want to wear heels that hurt, just to look “presentable.”

I want to dress for myself.
To be comfortable.
To be taken seriously for my work - not my eyeliner.

And men - you face this too.
The tall guy in a suit and expensive watch is instantly seen as a leader.
The shorter man in a simple shirt is often underestimated, no matter how sharp his mind is.

Looks fade.
Trends fade.
But skills, grit, and character don’t.

Workplaces need to value substance over style.
Because people come here to work - not to walk a runway.

Because here’s the truth:

No one remembers the shade of lipstick you wore to a meeting.

But they will remember the ideas you brought,
the problems you solved,
and the integrity you carried.

Red lipstick fades.
But skills, grit, and character - they don’t.

You earn ₹1,00,000 a month.

But spend ₹60,000 on therapy, medicines, and stress relief.

That’s not income.
That’s recovery cost.

Choose wisely.

LinkedIn feed today:

One guy: “Thrilled to announce my promotion!”

Next guy: “Thrilled to announce my layoff!”

Another guy: “Thrilled to announce my cat learned SQL.”

Meanwhile me: Thrilled to announce… nothing. Just scrolling, silently judging. 

At this point, LinkedIn isn’t a professional network - it’s a mix of Bigg Boss, Shark Tank, and Comedy Circus.

But here’s the bright side -
Not all wins are meant for the feed. Some wins are small, invisible, and deeply personal.
Like the fact you didn’t give up today. Or that you opened your laptop even when you didn’t feel like it. Or that you’re still here, still trying.

Your journey is valid even if it’s not “announcement-worthy.”

One day, your update will inspire someone who’s silently scrolling right now. 🌸

So don’t compare your chapter 1 to someone else’s chapter 20.

Keep moving, keep growing, and keep believing.

To all job seekers scrolling right now - 
Don’t lose hope.

Behind the “thrilled to announce” posts, everyone has their struggles too.

Keep applying, keep learning, and keep showing up.

Your announcement is loading… just wait for the right timing. ⏳🌟

Because your story is unfolding beautifully - even if today it looks like silence. ✨

Jobseekers, this one’s for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-up… the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isn’t about you or your skills. It’s about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesn’t acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. 🌻
Looking for jobs on LinkedIn is like online dating: Full of promises, but in the end, you’re just left ghosted.

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasn’t nothing. It was the Universe’s way of saying, “Not this one, something better is on the way.”

Every single time, I’ve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things don’t go as planned, I don’t panic.

I don’t question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you can’t see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. 💔

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. 🌸

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. 💥

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a company’s brand name doesn’t define someone’s talent. It’s easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

I’ve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They don’t need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side too—people in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Let’s stop attaching someone’s value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear this—skills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth don’t come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.
